results.title: Could do better
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
In this film Jim Douglas Henry looks at those children who suffer from dyslexia, and asks several questions: Is enough being done for dyslexic children? Why do some experts argue that dyslexia is nothing but a label used to excuse backward children?

results.title: Cough and you'll deafen thousands
results.brief_description: Offered as a tribute to the thousands of British broadcasting engineers whose initiative, inventiveness and skill have enabled British radio and television to achieve its present position, this film traces the growth of broadcasting from the first experiments in a hut at Writtle, Essex, to the coverage of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. Told by the men who were actually involved, the story is both amusing and informative.

results.title: Couchman on customer service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Couchman over Australia”.
Couchman addresses the issue of the quality of customer service and asks how are we to survive in the competitive and cut-throat nineties. Examples of good and bad customer service are shown in a discussion about the tactics for enduring the recession.

results.title: Cotton: from fiber to fabric
results.brief_description: Illustrates the partnership of science and nature in producing today’s version of the fibre which has served the human race for 5,000 years. Time-lapse photography shows the cotton plants emerging from the ground, growing, flowering and growing fruit. Animated drawings show the cellular development and structure of the cotton fibre. The wonders of the laboratory are shown where new finishes make modern cottons crease and wrinkle resistant, easier to care for, waterproof and stainproof.

results.title: Cotton in today's world
results.brief_description: Through scenes filmed in Egypt, India, Mexico, Indonesia and England, this film presents a brief historical background of the growing of cotton and indicates its important place in the economy of the world today. Modern American methods of growing, spraying, picking and ginning cotton are shown as well as some of the finished products.

results.creator_credit: Julien Bryan, International Film Foundation and Hermann Schlenker

results.title: Cotton goods
results.creator_credit: Eastman Teaching Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Shows the picking, ginning, bailing, and sale of cotton; the carding, twisting, and drawing of yarn; the production of thread; the weaving and testing of cotton fabrics; and some of the multiple uses of cotton in everyday life.

results.title: Cotton by computer
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Researchers”.
At Narrabri in New South Wales, CSIRO scientists are collaborating with the State Department of Agriculture and cotton farmers in the cause of more efficient production of cotton. A computer based management system is helping them find the best ways of managing the cotton crop, to use fewer pesticides and to increase the harvest.

results.title: Cotton
results.brief_description: Shows hand and machine picking of cotton in the United States, followed by extraction of seeds by gin. Also explains how the cotton is baled, cleaned, fluffed, carded, spun into yarn, and finally woven into cloth.
